[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Argument Injection] Can an attacker inject additional malicious arguments into the `arguments` VecDeque after `extract_function_info()` removes the last argument, causing the dispatched function to execute with attacker-controlled parameters leading to fund theft? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Dispatch Bypass] Can an attacker craft a FunctionDispatch error with a system module (0x1) and privileged function name to bypass access controls and execute admin-only operations like minting unlimited tokens? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Reentrancy Attack] Can a malicious dispatched function call back into the dispatchable system before the original dispatch completes, causing reentrancy that enables double-spending or unlimited withdrawals? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Cross-Module Exploit] Can an attacker dispatch to a compromised module that then dispatches back to a different fungible asset type, bypassing type safety and enabling cross-asset theft or minting? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Recursive Dispatch] Is there protection against recursive dispatch calls where a dispatched function triggers another dispatchable operation, potentially causing stack overflow or infinite gas consumption? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Dispatch Chain Manipulation] Can an attacker create a chain of dispatches that progressively escalate privileges or bypass security checks by exploiting state changes between dispatch calls? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Bypass] Can an attacker exploit the `check_visited` logic to skip the `DISPATCHABLE_FUNGIBLE_ASSET_DISPATCH_BASE` gas charge, enabling free execution of unlimited dispatchable operations and DoS attacks? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Front-Running] Can an attacker craft a transaction that charges minimal gas in `native_dispatch()` but dispatches to an expensive function, causing validators to waste resources and potentially halting the network? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Undercharge] Does the flat `DISPATCHABLE_FUNGIBLE_ASSET_DISPATCH_BASE` fee properly account for the cost of complex dispatched functions, or can attackers exploit underpriced operations to drain validator resources? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Race Condition] Can concurrent calls to `native_dispatch()` race on the `check_visited()` call, allowing some operations to execute without gas charges when the module is simultaneously being loaded? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Oracle Manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate feature flags or traversal context state to always pass `check_visited()` checks without actual gas charges, enabling unlimited free operations? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Gas Estimation Attack] Can an attacker provide a dispatch target with unpredictable gas costs that appear cheap but execute expensively, bypassing gas limit checks and causing validator DoS? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/dispatchable_fungible_asset.rs] [Function: native_dispatch()] [Check Visited Bypass] Can an attacker craft a module address/name combination that always passes the `check_is_special_or_visited()` check without actual verification, bypassing security controls?
